pullRequest.body:
Formalize Hoeffding's lemma using the property of cumulant.

Co-authored-by: Yuma Mizuno [mizuno.y.aj@gmail.com](mailto:mizuno.y.aj@gmail.com)

---

- [x] depends on: #20151

nodes.body:
### PR summary [6b24fd9ea7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18091/commits/6b24fd9ea7e3e00f8354936ec30e7c372dcddbbf)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Probability.Hoeffding` (new file)|2242|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ analyticAt_iteratedDeriv_cgf`
`+ analyticOnNhd_iteratedDeriv_cgf`
`+ analyticOn_iteratedDeriv_cgf`
`+ cgf_deriv_eq_tilted_measure_expectation`
`+ cgf_iterated_deriv_two_eq_tilted_measure_variance`
`+ cgf_le_bound_of_ae_mem_Icc_and_mean_zero`
`+ differentiableAt_cgf`
`+ differentiableAt_iteratedDeriv_cgf`
`+ hoeffding`
`+ integrableExpSet_of_ae_mem_Icc`
`+ integrable_exp_of_ae_const_le`
`+ integrable_exp_of_ae_le_const`
`+ mem_interior_integrableExpSet_of_ae_mem_Icc`
`- aemeasurable_exp_mul`
`- integrable_exp_mul_of_le`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> Thanks for the PR! It will require some changes because apparently you missed that we have definitions for the moment and cumulant generating functions. See [ProbabilityTheory.mgf](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Probability/Moments.html#ProbabilityTheory.mgf). You should use those definitions, and move their properties to the Moments file.

I got it. I'll move the lemmas about the first and derivatives of mgf and cgf to Probability/Moments file.
Thank you for writing many comments. It will take some time to fix everything, so please wait a moment

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20151~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

I merged master but did not make other changes to reuse the newly merged results from #20151 .
If you don't mind I'll make another commit with those changes later today.
~~Sorry if this was already discussed above, but can you generalise from bounded random variables to subgaussian random variables?~~ Got confused
Thank you for these comments.
Very exciting!

Thanks for the PR!
It will require some changes because apparently you missed that we have definitions for the moment and cumulant generating functions. See [ProbabilityTheory.mgf](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Probability/Moments.html#ProbabilityTheory.mgf).
You should use those definitions, and move their properties to the Moments file.
Here is a next batch of comments.
Very exciting!

```suggestion
    filter_upwards [rnDeriv_tilted_left_self (hX.const_mul t)] with ω w
```
See https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html#citing-other-works for how to properly cite other works in Mathlib.

```suggestion
Hoeffding's lemma, cumulant
```

```suggestion
lemma integrable_expt_bound [IsFiniteMeasure μ] {X : Ω → ℝ} {t a b : ℝ} (hX : AEMeasurable X μ)
```
We already have [ProbabilityTheory.mgf_pos'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Probability/Moments.html#ProbabilityTheory.mgf_pos')

You already proved [MeasureTheory.memℒp_of_bounded](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Function/LpSeminorm/Basic.html#MeasureTheory.mem%E2%84%92p_of_bounded) so you could use first [MeasureTheory.memℒp_one_iff_integrable](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Function/L1Space.html#MeasureTheory.mem%E2%84%92p_one_iff_integrable) and then the Lp result.

```suggestion
    (Ne.symm (ne_of_lt (mgf_pos' (NeZero.ne μ) (integrable_expt_bound μ hX h))))
```

```suggestion
    (mgf_pos' (NeZero.ne μ) (integrable_expt_bound μ hX h)).ne'
```
even
You could have a much shorter proof: this is a bounded function, hence integrable.
You removed the `awaiting-author` label, but that comment is still unresolved
This is the `cgf`, and the next two `have` are generic properties of the `cgf`. You should write them as independent lemmas. It looks like the first `have` is `cgf_zero`.
the statement you have in that `suffices` is a bound on `cgf`, which should be turned into a lemma.

```suggestion
    Integrable X μ :=
  memℒp_one_iff_integrable.mp
    memℒp_of_bounded h (aestronglyMeasurable_iff_aemeasurable.mpr hX)
```

That result should hold more generally than for bounded random variables. Can you generalize it?
Is `h` used only to get integrability properties, or in a more essential way?

I wrote the PR #20151 to prove more generally that the mgf is analytic on the interior of its domain (without any bounded support assumption), and give the values of its derivatives. See `hasDerivAt_mgf` in that PR.
I suggest we wait for my PR to be merged and then use it here.
Makes sense! Waiting for #20151 to be merged would be the better approach here

If I understand correctly, your goal before that `suffices` has the shape `Integrable ... → HasDerivAt ...` and you replace that implication by `Integrable ... ∧ HasDerivAt ...` for the same functions. That's just making the goal harder, so I don't understand why you do that. Am I missing something?

I'm trying to apply `hasDerivAt_integral_of_dominated_loc_of_deriv_le` (Derivative of Integral of Functions with Bounded Derivatives in a Neighborhood), and the conclusion of the statement is `Integrable (F' x₀) ∧ HasDerivAt (fun n => ∫ (a : α), F n a ∂μ) (∫ (a : α), F' x₀ a ∂μ) x₀`, so I had to arrange it in that way.
Same remark as for the `suffices` in the lemma above.

```suggestion
    (t : ℝ) (f : ℝ → ℝ) {X : Ω → ℝ} (hX : AEMeasurable X μ) :
```

An example of a way you can make your code shorter:
```suggestion
    refine integral_congr_ae (ae_of_all μ fun a ↦ ?_)
```
Extract that as a lemma?
I’m not sure how to extract this part as a lemma when using 'f' to show the proof briefly.

This is just a particular case of Taylor's theorem, so should be true for any function under enough differentiability conditions. I guess you use the definition of `f` only to show those conditions.

Actually Mathlib already has various statements for Taylor's theorem here: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Taylor.html . Perhaps one of them can help you golf this proof?

Also you should remove the `∀ x : ℝ`, as there is no `x` in the statement.

An example of using dot notation:
```suggestion
    apply hoeffding_nonneg _ _ _ _ _ (by linarith : 0 ≤ - t) hX.neg
```

```suggestion
      (hX.mono_ac (tilted_absolutelyContinuous μ fun ω ↦ t * X ω))
```

The code is shorter while being just as readable if you don't split `h` into `ha` and `hb`. Given that you split `h` like that everywhere, I guess that it's to reuse the proofs that you had when the two hypotheses were separated in the statements. Please adapt the code to the new hypothesis shape.
And I suppose that you unfold `mgf` and `cgf` for the same reason: please don't, where possible. It's better to not unfold the definition unless needed, as it allows us to spot where a generic property of those definitions should be used instead of an ad-hoc computation.

```suggestion
  apply MeasureTheory.Integrable.bdd_mul'
    (integrable_bounded a b X hX h) (aemeasurable_expt _ _ hX)
  · set c := max ‖a‖ ‖b‖
    filter_upwards [h] with ω h
    have q0 : ‖rexp (t * X ω)‖ ≤ ‖rexp (|t| * c)‖ := by
      simp only [norm_eq_abs, abs_exp, exp_le_exp]
      rw [← (abs_eq_self.mpr (le_trans' (le_max_left |a| ‖b‖) (abs_nonneg a)) : |c| = c)]
      calc
      _ ≤ |t * X ω| := le_abs_self (t * X ω)
      _ = |t| * |X ω| := abs_mul t (X ω)
      _ ≤ |t| * |c| :=
        mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_left (le_trans' (le_abs_self (max ‖a‖ ‖b‖))
          (abs_le_max_abs_abs h.1 h.2) : |X ω| ≤ |c|) (abs_nonneg t)
    exact q0
```

If you have a `have p0` followed by `exact p0`, then you could just prove it directly.

```suggestion
      change ‖rexp ((2 * |t| + 1) * |X ω|)‖ ≤ ‖rexp ((2 * |t| + 1) * c)‖  -- perhaps not needed
      simp only [norm_eq_abs, abs_exp, exp_le_exp]
      rw [← (abs_eq_self.mpr (le_trans' (le_max_left |a| ‖b‖) (abs_nonneg a)) : |c| = c)]
      exact mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_left
        (le_trans' (le_abs_self (max ‖a‖ ‖b‖)) (abs_le_max_abs_abs ha hb))
        (by linarith [abs_nonneg t] : 0 ≤ 2 * |t| + 1)
```

```suggestion
This file states Hoeffding's lemma, which says that bounded random variables are subgaussian.
```
It would be nice to prove the more general theorem that a bounded random variable (with no mean zero assumption) is subgaussian (rather than having subgaussian MGF)

To "remove" the mean zero assumption it's possible to write an immediate corollary of the current result: if `X` is bounded in an interval then `X - E[X]` is also bounded in an interval (of same length as `X`), so has sub-Gaussian moment generating function.

If you are thinking about proving one of the other properties called sub-Gaussian, then please tell us which one! And that's probably for another PR to avoid scope creep on this one.

```suggestion
    ∀ {t}, 0 ≤ t → t ∈ integrableExpSet X μ := by
```
same below

```suggestion
lemma mem_integrableExpSet_of_ae_le_const [IsFiniteMeasure μ] {X : Ω → ℝ} (b : ℝ)
```
same below

This lemma is the same as `integrable_exp_mul_of_le`, which is in Mathlib, in Moments/Basic.
In this PR you delete `integrable_exp_mul_of_le` and add this new `integrable_exp_of_ae_le_const` here. I don't see why. Could you revert that?

```suggestion
lemma integrableExpSet_of_ae_mem_Icc [IsFiniteMeasure μ] {X : Ω → ℝ} (a b : ℝ)
```

```suggestion
theorem mem_interior_integrableExpSet_of_ae_mem_Icc [IsFiniteMeasure μ] {X : Ω → ℝ} (t a b : ℝ)
```

```suggestion
theorem deriv_cgf_eq_integral_tilted {X : Ω → ℝ} (t : ℝ)
```
This lemma and the next one are now in Mathlib, in `Mathlib.Probability.Moments.Tilted` (in a more general version for the one on the variance, without any bounded assumption).

```suggestion
    iteratedDeriv 2 (cgf X μ) t = Var[X ; μ.tilted fun ω ↦ t * X ω] := by
```
and everywhere else

According to the linter, [X; μ.tilted fun ω ↦ t * X ω] would be more appropriate
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18091#discussion_r1993018275

Pointy brackets right-associate:
```suggestion
  obtain ⟨c, _, cq'⟩ := q
```

```suggestion
private theorem hoeffding_nonneg [IsProbabilityMeasure μ]
```
since it is superseded by the lemma below
Can you state this using the new `HasSubgaussianMGF` predicate?

As I wrote in a previous comment, I still think that you should extract a lemma here. Please write a lemma about a generic real function f with derivatives f' and f''. This is a very useful particular case of Taylor's theorem and merits it's own lemma, especially since it's apparently not so easily derived from the more general versions in Mathlib.
Can you revert that change?

pullRequest.title: feat: Hoeffding's lemma

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: `fun ω ↦ exp (t * X ω)` is integrable if `X` is bounded above
